html.p: As written, datagen one will produce a variable data volume, but in my last run it consumed 500 MB of data for 1.25 months. Recommend you set this up on a lab instance where you don't care. Running the datagen is simple: Just run: /opt/splunk/bin/splunk cmd /opt/splunk/etc/apps/conf_2014_security_ninjustu_dveuve/bin/generatePAN.pl. There are two expectations of this script -- the first is that you have your Splunk installed at /opt/splunk. If you don't, you'll need to modify that command accordingly, and also modify the script with a new $SPLUNK_HOME. You should also check the inputs.conf, as I ended up hardcoding the /opt/splunk path there too. There is a companion script to this that provides the actual malicious content. In addition to the background noise script (generateCarbonBlack.pl) you will find generatePANMalicious.pl which actually generates the suspect entries.

If you wish to decrease the data volume, you can tweak the number of records per day, but note that it is a very misleading named variable. The actual math is in number of records per second, so per day / 24 / 60 / 60 * randomness factor. If you were to set it to 500 records per day, none would actually be generated because the per second rate is too low.
